lesson_metadata.lesson_title: A Picture Is Worth a Thousand Words

items: I can use a reasonable scale for a graph modeling a situation.
I can identify the independent and dependent quantities for a situation.
I can identify key characteristics of graphs.

feature_data.content: Consider the situation and quantity pairs shared by your teacher. Prepare to share your thinking with your classmates.

Graphs relay information about relationships in a visual way. You can use lines or smooth curves to represent relationships between points on a graph. In some problem situations, all the points on the line will make sense. In other problem situations, not all the points will make sense. So, when you model a relationship with a line or a curve, it is up to you to consider the situation and interpret the meaning of the data values.

items: Cut out the graphs provided by your teacher. Then, read each of the six situations in this activity.
Determine the independent and dependent quantities.
Match each situation to its corresponding graph. Glue the graph next to the situation.
For each graph, label the x- and y-axis with the appropriate quantity and a reasonable scale, and then interpret the meaning of the origin.

feature_data.content: Jared completes a dive from a cliff 100-feet above a river. It takes him only 1.7 seconds to hit the water.

callout.content: Be sure to include the appropriate units of measure for each quantity.

content_blocks.content: Dependent quantity: Jared’s height above the water (feet)

image.alt_text: A graph titled 'Graph E' showing a downward curving line, representing Jared's height above water versus time. The y-axis (height) goes from 0 to 100 feet, and the x-axis (time) goes from 0 to 2 seconds.
image.caption: Graph E

feature_data.content: Parker is cleaning a 200-gallon office aquarium. She removes the fish and drains the water at a constant rate of 10 gallons per minute.

callout.content: What strategies will you use to match each graph with one of the six situations?

image.alt_text: A graph titled 'Graph F' showing a straight line decreasing from 200 gallons to 0 over 10 minutes.
image.caption: Graph F

features.feature_title: 3. Smart Phone, But Is It a Smart Deal?

feature_data.content: You want an upgraded smartphone but lack the funds. Your cousin offers to lend you the money with interest, starting at $1 and doubling weekly. You wonder if it’s a good deal.

image.alt_text: A graph titled 'Graph B' showing an upward curving exponential line representing weekly interest.
image.caption: Graph B

feature_data.content: Juniper, the Altadena High drum major, tosses her baton 22 feet high during the halftime finale, giving her 2 seconds to twirl twice and catch it.

image.alt_text: A graph titled 'Graph D' showing a parabolic curve representing the height of a baton over time.
image.caption: Graph D

feature_data.content: The number of guests at a ski resort depends on the day’s high temperature. No one visits at -20°F or below. As temperatures rise, guests increase. At 0°F and above, attendance surges, reaching the 400-guest capacity at 10°F or higher.

image.alt_text: A graph titled 'Graph A' showing the number of guests increasing with temperature, then plateauing.
image.caption: Graph A

feature_data.content: Mr. Vasquez judges the Jelly Bean Challenge at the summer fair, recording all possible guesses and how far each is from the actual count.

content_blocks.content: Independent quantity: Number of jelly beans guessed
Dependent quantity: Number of jelly beans the guess is off by
Origin: (0 jelly beans guessed, 0 jelly beans the guess is off by)

image.alt_text: A graph titled 'Graph C' showing a V-shape, representing the error in a jelly bean guess.
image.caption: Graph C

features.feature_title: 7. Compare the graphs for each pair of situations given.

feature_data.content: Describe any similarities and differences you notice.

callout.content: Look closely when analyzing the graphs. What do you see?

sub_problems.title: a. Smart Phone, But Is It a Smart Deal? and Cold Weather
sub_problems.answer:
Sample answers:
Both graphs increase from left to right.
The graph of the Smart Phone, But Is It a Smart Deal? situation is a smooth curve, but the graph of the Cold Weather situation is composed of two increasing and one constant line segments.

sub_problems.title: b. Something’s Fishy and Daredevil
sub_problems.answer:
Sample answers:
Both graphs decrease from left to right.
The graph of the Something’s Fishy situation is a straight line, but the graph of the Daredevil situation is a smooth curve.

sub_problems.title: c. Baton Twirling and Jelly Bean Challenge
sub_problems.answer:
Sample answers:
The graphs have either a minimum or a maximum value. Both graphs increase and decrease.
The graph of the Baton Twirling situation is a smooth curve, but the graph of the Jelly Bean Challenge situation is made up of two straight lines.

feature_data.content: Write a situation and sketch a graph to describe a possible trip to school.

content_blocks.content:
Sample answer:
I walk half a mile to school in 10 minutes. Then, I stop to talk to a friend and tie my shoes for 5 minutes. I walk the remaining half-mile to school in 10 minutes.

image.alt_text: A graph showing distance traveled versus time for a trip to school, with three distinct line segments.
image.caption: Graph

feature_data.content: Describe the meaning of the points, or smooth curve, represented by your graph.

content_blocks.content:
Sample answer:
Each point on the graph represents possible times and the corresponding distances.

feature_data.content: Compare your situation and sketch with your classmates’ situations and sketches. What similarities do you notice? What differences do you notice?
Determine the independent and dependent quantities in each situation. Be sure to include the appropriate units of measure for each quantity.

items: Baila reads a 300-page book at a rate of 20 pages per hour.
A car wash business charges $15 per car for a basic wash.
Ashley drinks water at a steady rate of 0.5 liters per 15 minutes while hiking.
A library allows users to borrow books for 2 weeks per loan period.
A group of friends purchases tickets to a concert. Tickets cost $75 each.
A hose fills a swimming pool at a rate of 8 gallons per minute.
The temperature drops 2 degrees Fahrenheit per hour overnight.
A construction company rents a bulldozer for $150 per day.
